overview: The purpose of this Act is to permanently establish the women's court program in the first circuit. [13] This measure also establishes a two-year women's court pilot program in the circuit court of the Kona division of the third circuit. [13] Additionally, it requires the judiciary to submit reports to the legislature regarding the pilot program for women's court. [13]
appropriations: There is appropriated out of the general revenues of the State of Hawaii the sum of $514,900 (HB727_CD1_.HTM.txt) for fiscal year 2025-2026 and $557,000 (HB727_CD1_.HTM.txt) for fiscal year 2026-2027. [13] These funds are for mental health, substance abuse treatment, and other services and equipment. [13] The appropriation also covers the establishment of one full-time equivalent (1.0 FTE) temporary Kona drug court probation supervisor position for the women's court pilot program. [13]
assumptions_and_methodology: The provided legislative documents do not specify the assumptions, cost estimation methods, or data sources used to calculate the financial projections for the pilot program. [13] The appropriations are presented as lump sums for services, equipment, and one temporary position. [13] No cost-benefit analysis or comparison to similar programs is included in the final bill text. [13]
agency_impact: There shall be established within the third circuit Kona division of the judiciary the women's court pilot program. [13] The women's court pilot program shall be under the supervision of the big island drug court. [13] The judiciary shall be responsible for providing mental health services under this pilot program. [13]
economic_impact: The goal of the program is to divert participants from incarceration, supporting their success in the community, and reducing recidivism. [13] The program focuses on non-violent women who are at high risk of recidivism and in need of multiple services such as substance abuse treatment, therapy, or housing. [13] As of August 2024, twenty-three women are currently participating in the existing First Circuit program. [13]
policy_impact: This measure codifies the Women's Court Program in the First Circuit within the Hawaii Revised Statutes, making it permanent. [14] It changes the duration of the Women's Court Pilot Program in the Kona division of the Third Circuit from three years to two years. [14] The Act also deletes language that would have required the Judiciary to submit a report on the need for similar programs in other circuits. [14]
revenue_sources: The program is funded by an appropriation out of the general revenues of the State of Hawaii. [13] The sum of $514,900 (HB727_CD1_.HTM.txt) is appropriated for fiscal year 2025-2026. [13] A sum of $557,000 (HB727_CD1_.HTM.txt) is appropriated for fiscal year 2026-2027. [13]
six_year_fiscal_implications: The measure appropriates $514,900 (HB727_CD1_CCR58_.htm.txt) for fiscal year 2025-2026 and $557,000 (HB727_CD1_CCR58_.htm.txt) for fiscal year 2026-2027 for the Kona pilot program. [14] The funds are designated for mental health, substance abuse treatment, other services, equipment, and one temporary full-time equivalent position. [14] The Kona pilot program is established for two years. [14] Part III of the Act, which establishes the Kona pilot, will be repealed on June 30, 2027. [13] The Women's Court Program in the First Circuit is made permanent, which will create ongoing fiscal obligations beyond the six-year period. [13] The cost for the permanent program is not specified in the bill. [13] The judiciary must submit reports to the legislature on the pilot program prior to the 2026 and 2027 regular sessions. [13] These reports will include recommendations on whether the pilot program should continue, expand, or be discontinued. [13]
operating_revenue_impact: The documents do not describe any anticipated impacts on operating revenues. [13] The program is supported by appropriations from the general revenues of the State of Hawaii. [13] There is no indication that the program will generate its own revenue stream. [13]
Full_Time_Equivalent_Positions: The measure includes funding for the establishment of one full-time equivalent (1.0 FTE) temporary Kona drug court probation supervisor position. [13]
capital_expenditure_impact: The appropriation includes an unspecified amount for equipment for the women's court pilot program. [13] The bill does not provide a detailed breakdown of these equipment costs. [13] No other major capital expenditures are mentioned in the measure. [13]
fiscal_implications_after_6_years: The Women's Court Program in the First Circuit is permanently established, which will result in ongoing fiscal obligations beyond the initial multi-year period. [13] The two-year women's court pilot program in the Kona division of the third circuit is repealed on June 30, 2027. [13] Any continuation or expansion of the Kona program would require new legislative action and appropriation. [13]
updates_from_previous_fiscal_note: The appropriations have been updated to specific amounts of $514,900 (HB727_CD1_CCR58_.htm.txt) for FY 2025-2026 and $557,000 (HB727_CD1_CCR58_.htm.txt) for FY 2026-2027, whereas the previous note indicated these amounts were unspecified. [14] The duration of the Kona pilot program has been changed from three years to two years, with a new sunset date of June 30, 2027. [14] The bill now only provides for one temporary FTE position, the Kona drug court probation supervisor, removing mention of a peer specialist or Department of Health positions. [14] A requirement for the Judiciary to report on the need for pilot programs in other circuits has been deleted. [14] The Judiciary is now explicitly required to be responsible for providing mental health services under the pilot program. [14]
